39364781.review:
TL:DR; A decent game that does what it says. Good fun, Much better with friends. But can feel alil rough around the edges at time. Worth 10$ in my mind. I think you will get your money's worth.


Long Review. This game can be alot of easy to get into fun. My only real issues are in two seperate regards. 

First the controls can feel really clunky at times. I know many users get motion sick when using trackpad controls, but the way the arm swinging/walking in place, style of walking works in this game just feels alil funny to me. Personally I DONT get motion sick playing... well just about anything to be completely honest. I seem to be immune. So for me I quickly switched over to trackpad movement. Which I am happy to report is an option in the full game. IT ISNT IN THE DEMO. 
which had me alil worried when I tried the demo. But sure enough it is there. With one minor issue. To walk at full speed you need to press BOTH track pad controlers in the same direction. Which I just find alil silly. This is the only game so far in my almost 80 VR game list that does it this way. So its not intuitive at all. I wish the Devs would just simply make the trackpad control the same as every other game.

Second issue is a more difficult to fix one however. I feel like the creators of this game are really limiting the creativity of this game in a major way by having only the most basic of textures for the terrain of the game. Sure this is really quick and easy to work with and super easy to learn for anyone who wants to play or make their own maps. But it makes it alot less interesting in the long run. Every map ends up feeling like an unfinished source map or something, with grid textures as far as the eye can see. I think it would be alot more interesting if there was just some more options as far as textures on the objects are concerned. This way when you download a workshop map of the effel tower you feel like your actually climbing it, and Default texture tower. 

However that being said the Devs have already taken a step in the right direction by allowing you to change your skybox to anything you want. So +1 to devs there. So if the Devs keep up the good work im sure this game will grow to be a great fun climbing game. And currently It is probably the best on the market anyway, so they have all the reason to keep updating it so they can hold that place.

39101606.review:
This is a really great example of proper VR mechanics. You will find yourself leaping around, jumping over gaps, reaching for the next ledge, and gingerly climbing up vertical walls, all while flailing around in real life. You jump or move by pushing the controllers behind you like skiies and you climb by gripping the virtual wall in real life. This is a physically active game but very engaging. It's also fantastic in multiplayer. You'll find yourself making a lot of quick arm movements, so stay in the middle of your play area!

I'd like to see a UI improvement to the menu system on the home environment, further graphical enhancements, and the helper robot seems a bit childish, but the levels themselves are well designed and reasonably difficult, so overall it's quite fun. You'll look pretty silly in real life but the experience is absolutely worth it.

Climbing works well.
Jumping, which is a very important part of the game, is totally broken - there is zero consistency or predictability. Sometimes you get launched into the stratosphere, sometimes barely get off the ground, sometimes you go sideways or backwards...

38044508.review:
I finished the included 15 levels in under 2 hours, but then got more off the workshop. Only tried one of them so far but it was awesome. Once you get a hang of the controls, they work very well, in fact this is my favorite mode of VR locomotion. I added a skybox and immediately hit the controller on a table from flailing my hands in a momentary, but real, panic as I fell. I removed the skybox as the greyness is still enough to make my vertigo act up. This is a must-own to show off VR.

Tip 1: Running uses the SIDE buttons. The first half hour I spent hopping in small jumps as movement.
Tip 2: Jumping is all about when you release the triggers. Your launch speed is best when you RELEASE AT HIGHEST CONTROLLER SPEED, not when the controller is at the end of your swing. Like golf or baseball, add a wrist flick in the swing and let the triggers go in the middle of that. Although some things are fun to discover on your own, this game sucks until you get the jumping figured out.

37900055.review:
Climbey is an awesome VR game with great vallue for its price!

I have been looking for a VR game like this for a while, was tempted to get The Climb but the price was holding me back (i will stil get it down the line i am sure!) Then i found out about Climbey, sure the graphics are nothing like The Climb, but those really dont matter in this game, its also a really different game. It has climbing ofcourse, but its also more of a VR platformer, you walk around, jump etc, there are moving platforms, spikes to avoid and ziplines! 

It also allows you to add a custom skybox, the standard one is just some blue sky and dark ground, nothing fancy but it works, but change it up with a Paris skybox and the immersion gets a major step up, before the custom skybox i wasnt really afraid of falling, but with my current custom Paris one you can really feel the hight you are at, really feel like you would fall, its crazy how much it changes.

There is workshop support too, so you have almost endless of content for Climbey, You have simple maps and then beyond crazy ones like an Assassins Creed style tower climb, there is something for everyone here and the creativity i have seen so far from creators is really amazing!

So in short:
Great VR game for the low price of only 10 Euros, workshop support that lets you get endless amount of new content, you cant go wrong with this one! Unless you are afraid of hights :)

Cheers,
Nivek

36539119.review:
I own the three major climbing games for vr (this, To the Top, & The Climb). They're all worth owning for their own reasons. The Climb has scenic views, feels the most realistic and was all around great (though it could really use more content, if I didn't get it in a bundle I'd have been disappointed at how much it was for the content). To the Top requires the least amount of movement (your hands have long reach, and you jump by grabbing with both hands, letting go and looking where you want to go)  and was disappointing at first, but grew on me while I tried finding all the gems and doing speed runs. It's fun if you give it the time to grow on you (though some of the music in that game REALLY doesn't want you to), and was worth it at the discount price I got it at.  This one I have spent the least amount of time on, but I can say it's not too bad and I'll come back to it eventually. It involves the most amount of arm movement of the three games. It takes a bit of practice, but it's pretty fun flinging yourself across the map in this game. This one has multiplayer too, so that's a thing if you're into that (To the Top plans on having it in an update). And it's the only one that doesn't feel a bit overpriced!

I post this mostly for those seeing these three games and trying to decide which is the best to get. They all have different mechanics, and very much feel like completely different games because of it. If you want "realistic" rock climbing (and the most exciting IMO), go for The Climb. If you want speedrunning and gem collecting with ease of use, go with To the Top. If you want to "throw" yourself across the map, get this game. While this one was my least favorite of the three I suppose, that's just my opinion and I can easily seeing it being the opposite for other people. It's still completely worth getting for the weird throwing movement, and is the one least likely to leave you with buyers remorse because of it's reasonable price point.  Or maybe get Sweet Escape, which is like the poor man's Climbey if this is still too pricey for your blood.

35923269.review:
Climbey is a quite simple and minimalistic climbing game for HTC Vive/Oculus Rift  but it convinces in so many ways. 

Anyone who ever climbed a ladder in a VR game knows how natural and satisfying it feels. Climbey increases that feeling by giving you the possibility to jump by swinging your hands down. You'll have to get used to it and I can only recommend to download the demo to try it out by yourself. Apart from the "normal" white surface that you can climb on there is a blue surface which will speed you up and get faster the more and harder you swing down with your hands. Also there some kind of rope slips.

Climbing alone can be fun but the best way to play Climbey is definetly the multiplayer mode. It has some beautiful cooperative mechanics and perfectly uses the VR technique. You can hold one of your hands in the air so your friends can grab it. Once they grabbed your hand you can also push them forward to reach the next step much easier and with less risk. You can grab your friends backpack or helmet as well to stick to them.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1173068792

In the evening/night (UTC) you will often have some players online to play with (be sure to check the steamdb site if you want to be sure).
Like most VR games Climbey uses open mic and I've already met some great, cooperative people and had a lot of good laughs.

There are quite a few default levels but there is an ingame level editor and steam workshop support for much more content. People already created a ton of beautiful, challenging and fun maps so there is always something new to play.

One thing I also need to mention is the possibility to use any 360 degree image as skybox because it adds a lot to the surrounding atmosphere and I would definetly recommend trying that. You can find some good city panoramas (which turned out to be the best kind of skybox) on the Climbey subreddit.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1174022863

Also you should beware that Climbey is one of those games where you have to be very careful with your enviroment. Even tho I played a lot of VR I still manage to hit especially my ceiling quite often in this game.

I also tried The Climb from Crytek (using Revive) but I have to say apart from the graphics, Climbey is better in every aspect. The climbing and jumping is much more fun, it has an awesome cooperative multiplayer and lots of content with the Steam Workshop support. Also it is much cheaper.

So what are you waiting for? If you own an HMD you shouldn't miss out Climbey, especially for the cheap price of 9,99€ it has a great value!

34980210.review: This game is amazing. I'm not sure why I took this long to put up a review when it's definitely one of my favorite (if not my favorite) game to play in VR. As someone who's had a pretty strong fear of heights, this game has surprisingly helped me overcome a bit of that fear and am now able to climb ladders with little anxiety. I ended up using a 360 photo of skyscrapers in Paris to add to the sensation and I believe one of the main reasons I was able to overcome some of that anxiety in real life. I still have moments where my feet and hands cramp up from levels that are open, difficult, and with very few checkpoints, but I actually enjoy these moments considering I've never felt this way outside of VR playing video games. I'd say this is a great game for seasoned VR players, but I'd extremely recommend it for those new to VR. I wish more games would adopt the climbing mechanics this game has brought to the table, but would like to see some map design and textures. The workshop features are also a great addition and probably the main reason I have so much time invested in this game. The game allows users, with creative minds, to build custom maps for the commuinity to download and play. I love it when theres a bunch of 4 or 5 star maps I haven't tried yet. They download in seconds so there's virtually no wait. This game is definitely a buy in my book and easily one I'd give 10-9.5/10.

The climbing and jumping mechanics pioneered by this game give you a great feeling of presence and agency over your movement. Crucially, I have found the multiplayer sessions to be surprising good, with most players willing to help out newer users with the somewhat steep learning curve. There are certainly frustrating parts to the game, but these are overshadowed by the pure satisfaction of simply overcoming them.

32729670.review:
Climbey is a fun if perfectible VR experience which, while a good introduction to more eccentric methods of locomotion, is lacking in content.

[h1]GRAPHICS[/h1]
By far not the game's strongest suit, Climbey has no art style to speak of. The minimalistic, purposefully WIP design is appreciable for how readable it makes each level, but the drawback is that the game is not particularly pretty or interesting to look at.

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
Climbey's whole premise is in its name: you climb. That's really all there is to it. Locomotion is both based on arm-swinging and dragging yourself along surfaces onto which you can hold, with one or both hands. The player's interaction with each surface is simple enough: white blocks can be grabbed, grey blocks cannot, blue (ice) blocks are slippery and red (lava) blocks kill on impact.

Past this, the game's fun factor entirely revolves around the levels themselves, which sadly aren't all good. The stock array of levels can be quite forgettable and often offer a single, fairly simple challenge based on one gimmick which varies every time. While user-created levels are often more daring and complex, if only for their attempts at being thematic (as much as the game's artstyle allows them, really), they are often extremely linear.

Another issue of gameplay is the jumping. It is possible to leap across relatively short distances (albeit still far exceeding the average human ability) by grabbing onto the air and pulling back. While timing helps, the actual results is still mostly random and only becomes more difficult to control over longer jumps - and a dangerously high amount of levels rely heavily on jumping across particularly long distances. This creates a big problem especially when the player has to jump backwards or while holding onto objects, dozens of meters above the nearest surface. Community-made levels in particular over-utilize long distance jumps to the point of being infuriating.

[h1]VR IMPLEMENTATION[/h1]
Climbey in its current form would not be playable without VR. Motion-tracked hands is integral to gameplay but room-scale is relatively unneeded: due to the rather physical nature of the game it is obviously better to stand up clear of any other objects, but it is possible to play the entire game without ever moving your legs. The option to enable 90° turning via the touchpads also makes it possible to play entirely still without turning around, especially useful if you are confined to a 180° playspace.

The game is relatively high on the discomfort scale: the lack of touchpad locomotion (arguably the most prone to causing simulation sickness) in favor of dragging/armswinging is rather comfortable in itself, but the game has a lot of forced movement in the form of slippery platforms, ziplines, trampolines and of course plenty of falling down. The sense of vertigo is also very prominent for obvious reasons and while the game does not pretend to be a cure for a fear of heights, enough time spent toying around with it will greatly dull the effect.

31267000.review:
I fucking love this game. I recommend this to anyone looking for a real Room-Scale game. Movement in this game feels so real. To run you grab the grip buttons and move your hands and arms like you would if you were actually running.. well unless you're weird and run with your hands down like you're an anime ninja. Anyway, you jump by basically grabbing the air and pulling yourself into a jump. A "Dyno" in rock climbing terms. I would recommend changing the direction movement to controller rather than headset. Makes walking thin platforms easier in my opinion. 

So what makes this game so cool for me was the community in the game. Games filled up pretty quick, though most of the time with VR games for me it seems to be the time of day and when a game is new. Overall multiplayer was smooth. No lag when anyone connected, I grouped up with about six people no problem, and no lag with other players. I actually ended up getting taught by some kid which I thought was rather interesting. He showed me how to propperly jump, assisted me in climbing, and even let me hop on his backpack when I couldn't land some jumps. It was honestly wicked cool of that kid to show me. But I also saw how easy it was to teach the game. You could literally hold your hand out as an extra grab point and pull up someone. You can point at things, talk to them, and just interact with them on such a deeper level than traditional gaming. Then to have a workshop setup where you can create your own map only blows up that potential. I thought I got pretty good when I was beating most of the default maps on my first run around 1 min laps. Some other guys joined and banged out the same run in 20 seconds. Some craazy shit when you think someone is actually moving like that in real life. 

Overall I am happy with my purcahse. 
If I could recommend anything I'd say I would just polish up graphics a bit. The game is still a work in progress so before I actually say anything negitive I'd like to point out any and all flaws could potentialy be fixed by the time you read this. Really my only complaint is that the tutorial is actually hard if you've never played, which is the purpose of tutorials. Some parts are easy while others take some pretty good accurracy and skill to land. Tutorial should be more basic climbing and make it more apparently you have the ability to set check points. I saw a board that said checkpoint in the beginning that was just there, but I quickly read it and moved onto whatever seemed like a play button. It just needs some better guiding with a more forgiving course. Like a hole that you could practice climbing out of instead of a bottomless pit.

29177852.review:
I was really quite surpsrised by Climbey. The graphics and art style leave a lot to be desired, but the rest of the game blew my expectations away.

Climbey is a fun, simple game with potentially infinite content. This is the exact type of game I want to see on VR. Easy to pick up yet is challenging, has responsive controls, and tons of non-repetitive content. It doesn't require a lot of room to play either, despite how much movement is in the game. Most of your real life movement will be arm flailing. Your character is far from stagnant, however. The walking mechanic has restored my faith that future VR titles can do locomotion well. It works well and feels natural. Jumping works just fine as well, but it's tricky to be accurate with it, and is one of the hardest parts of the game. I'm not sure if I have just gotten more use to VR or if it's the natural movements you have to make with your body to walk and jump in this game, but I did not feel any m otion sickness.

The user created levels expand the potential content of this game to the moon.  It's fun sitting in a lobby with other players and listent to the chit chat as every tries to make it through a course someone created.

The game is a bit physically demanding. Not to a great degree, but enough to break you out in a sweat. Just know what you're getting into. This is not a relax and unwind kind of game.

I think Climbey is a must-have for new VR owners. Don't pass it up because it looks lackluster like I did initially. Looks can be deceiving.

29142821.review: I strongly recommend this game and feel it is a must have for anyone with VR. The movement in the game feels very fluid and the controls are very intuitive. As someone who has a fear of heights, this game is frighteningly immersive but addicting enough for me to overcome my fears. I have not yet tried the multiplayer but it seems like it takes the entertainment value to even greater heights. I'm excited to see this game grow.

28734451.review:
My favourite VR game. It doesn't utilise the teleportation method of travel as most VR games do and I absolutely love it for that. It's much more immersive needing to skillfully jump to get around, with the bonus of being able to run by swaying the controllers back and forth similar to running in place. Also has multiplayer and that's a huge plus for me; not many VR games currently support multiplayer and the few ones that do are also the highest rated -- surely not a coincidence, it's fun to interect with others in VR. 

Simple Pro/Con list for lovers of TL;DR-style: 

PROS:

Multiplayer if you can manage to get players together for it. You can even grab onto other players' hands and they can help pull you up if you're struggling to progress. Lion King all over again. 

Level editor. Not a big fan of it since it's in VR mode and not on the desktop, but it exists and for those people willing to stand up in their room for possibly hours and meticulously craft a level, I appreciate your dedication. 

Immersive movement. I can run, jump, and even use gestures with other players. Not everybody's a fan of manual movement and they might prefer teleportation to avoid nauseau, but I personally love it. 

Challenging, but not because I feel limited in what I can do. (like in other VR games) 

Updated frequently. (As of December, 2016)

You can play "Rock, Paper, Scissors" with people online. Or just flip them off. I'm not judging anybody. 

Great workout: Save money on gym, flail arms around in your room while wearing expensive blindfold, profit.

A good amount of content for the price. Also a good amount of custom levels, some of which are very nicely-designed maps.

CONS:

Not many players, but as this game does have niche appeal, it's understandable. It's also a game that can be very physically demanding to play with all of the motions involved, so what players are around will likely tire out quickly.

It can be very buggy at times. It's not fair to dock anything for this as the game's freedom of controls allows for many variables and in general this isn't a rare issue with VR games as they're all early designs. There are a few technical issues, but nothing as severe as crashing or being unplayable. Again -- fully expected to have lots to iron out with a game like this. I hope to see this game a lot more polished in the future. 

Minimal graphics. For some probably too minimal. I personally like the clean look, wouldn't mind a few more choices for aesthetic.



Final thoughts:

Would love to see a desktop version of the level editor included and more graphical options since the game is fairly barebones in its appearance so far. Aside from those gripes, it's my favourite VR game and at a great price.

In short this game made me request a refund. Not because the game itself is bad don't get me wrong it's one of my favourites but I strongly believe that there just isn't enough of the game to enjoy; not to mention the free demo you can get which show cases EVERYTHING about the game (I've spent more time in the demo then I have the game). The novelty just wears off and now that I'm more or less used to VR now it's become a worse experience for me. Many would argue that the steam workshop combatability creates limitless gameplay (to which I'd agree) it DOES not add new mechanics which the game in my opinion desperately needs. 

+The graphics are simplistic and cartoon-inspired which takes away the realism yet somehow adds to the fun.
+Adrenaline is created through the vast heights and jumps you can make, but the novelty wears off 
+/- The robot is nice...? But I'd like to see him input more based on what you're doing and not what level you're on
-The mechanics and novelty for me PERSONALLY just wear off too quickly to replay
-The free demo is better then the game to a certain extent
-The running locomotion is useless, found my self bunny hopping more then walking around

Overall the game is still very nice and the potential here is large, this, in the future could be part of a massive open world VR genre and it brung out the inner parkour machine in me. But as of right now the ammount of default levels and game mechanics make my future with the game obselete.

28525714.review:
The amount of damage done to the ceiling in my room is a testement to how utterly engrossing this game can be. Yes the graphics are insanely simplistic but this is one of those titles that works because of it, the experience is what its about. 

The general goal is to...well reach a goal. However you have to navigate challenging maps to do so, using as you might imagine climbing as your primary tool. You will hang, leap, slide, lunge and fall to victory through the included maps, which get you little by little use to the game. when your ready hit up the workshop and see what the internet has thrown at you.

There is multiplayer, which is a blast, and its a ton of fun to race other players to the finish. The sense of excitement you can feel sometime soaring through the air is just unreal. Its hard to do this type of game justice with a written review, but luckily i dont really have to, as there is a FREE demo that lets you try out a practice map. I do not think there is anything i can say to convince you to spend your 10 bucks on this more than that demo.

For newbie VR users, my advice: do not look down.

28480163.review:
Okay, WOW. Love, Love, Love this game. I play on the HTC Vive and this is easily my most played title already, and why? Let me give you a list:

1. I get motion-sick when moving around in VR when my body isnt actually moving. This game almost completely ELIMINATED that by trikcing my brain into thinking I was moving. I don't feel any symptoms of motion-sickness until after an hour of gameplay!

2. Most intuitive movement control system I've experience.

3. Physics of falling and propelling yourself are good, although, you can jump like a grasshopper. That can be a bit disorienting.

4. Steam Workshop Integration. I cannot stress how important this is. There are only 15 levels built in, the rest are all user made! Super cool, in my opinion.

5. Multiplayer is good. Helping friends is neat, and voice chat is integrated.

6. Add your own skyboxes and change your player color. Is there anything these guys didn't think of?

Cons? Not many.

1. The in game level creator / editor isn't very easy to use. I'm a slow learner though, so perhaps thats just me.

2. Sometimes I notice a bug whilst walking, my game doesn't always register that I've let go of the grip buttons and try to keep walking. I have to click them again to make them register. I don't think this is limited to my Vive Controllers.

Aside from that, GREAT GAME! Keep up the great work!

Who'd have thought first-person-platformer in VR would be thing, and that it'd be so much damn fun?

This is a gem of a game that is innovative, makes great use of VR, and is a blast to play alone or with others. The mechanics are simple, easy to get the hang of, and suprisingly free of any motion sickness. The level editor and drop-in multiplayer will keep you coming back, and the ability to change skyboxes (the background of where your climbing) lets you completely alter the atmosphere of the game.

28261455.review:
Best VR game experience and value, for me, to date. 

I have just under 20 games. Many of the puzzle/adventure games are great but they are more expensive, low on content, and offer little to no replay-ability. This on the other hand is the game I keep coming back to. 

The single player is not incredibly long but that doesn't matter. That's basically the tutorial. The multiplayer is where it's at. You log into the game and join one of the servers or make your own. You can choose from a plethora of created maps or make your own inside the VR level editor, which is amazing in itself. Proximity chat makes it easy to talk to the other players and the community has been very chill.

As others stated, you will get a little workout in here. You will have a sweaty hands and face in no time as you make your way across these maps, and it is totally worth it. Can not recommend this game enough - if you have one game to buy, this is it.

28247003.review:
Like many other reviewers, I was initially turned off by the bland graphics and simple premise. It's like Mario 64 in VR - except no plot, no colors, no enemies, and no music. But once you step in and start jumping around, it's wild fun. You're scrambling up ledges, out of breath and hands sweaty, arms sore, then trying to time a jump onto a moving platform, and when you make it you feel like the coolest person in the world. Once you master the built-in maps, there's a large and growing collection of player-made maps to test your skills on.

And once you try out multiplayer, there's no going back. Doing Tarzan leaps around a giant playground with five other people (in the snow! With santa hats!), giving someone a thumbs-up, or reaching out to grab someone's hand because you can't reach the ledge, is super addictive. The voice chat is nicely done; a player's voice gets louder when you're close to them so there's a real sense of space and distance, and it's hilarious to hear people yell in despair as they miss a jump.

Whenever it's time for a VR break, I glance over my library of games, all of which have "more things to do" and/or much prettier graphics than Climbey does. Then I boot up Climbey anyway and hop into a multiplayer room, because that's the experience that I look forward to the most.

26590483.review:
I never knew VR Platforming was a thing and now that I've tried it I can't get enough of it. In Climbey you traverse massive levels by climbing, jumping, and walking through various obstacles in order to reach a destination. The most important thing with these kinds of games is accurate and satisfying movement and I feel that the developers have found that "Super Meat Boy" sweet spot in excellent traversal mechanics. The best thing about this game is that the movement for me (FYI I am very prone to motion sickness) did not cause me to get nauseas.

Another great aspect of this game is the fact that you can climb with other people. The experience is a lot like AltSpace or Rec Room in that you can carry on conversations and interact physcially with people that are half-way across the world from you. Hell, I just played with a bunch of Frenchman (I live in the United States) and it was a lot of fun getting to talk and interact with people that come from a competely different continent from me. 

[b] TL;DR [/b]

This is a great VR game that any Vive owner can throw a couple of hours into. If you are a person that can't stand playing normal platforming games then this probably isn't the game for you. But, for those of you who get addicted to games like Flappy Bird or Cat Mario this game has that "one more try" feel to it.

26424999.review:
First and foremost - the actual core mechanics of this game are awesome.  The climbing feels great, the jumping feels AMAZING once you get the hang of it, and the comfort options mean that I don't feel any sickness whatsoever.  

Before I jump into how I don't like a lot of this game, I want to emphasize that I still recommend it.  It's still a ton of fun, and the core mechanics are almost enough to carry the game, but there ARE issues.  These are issues that are pretty much entirely due to level design, which can be fixed by the developer.

It's early access, so poor level design is something that might improve, but the levels that come with the game feel like they were thrown together.  It really does not feel like any care or time was put into most of the levels past the tutorials.  The major problems are:

- Difficulty curve that is all over the place.  Some levels have ridiculously precise jumps from walls that you need to do.  Then after those, you have some levels that are ridiculously easy, with almost no challenge at all.  The game lets you specify 3 checkpoints of your own per level, but some levels are so long that that is not nearly enough, and some levels are so short that even using 1 seems like overkill.

- Lots and lots of waiting.  Most levels have moving platforms of some sort, and when you screw up, you'll spend a solid 5-10 seconds waiting for a platform to come back.  I got to what I think was level 10 or 11, with several platforms that each seemed to take over 10 seconds to rotate back around, and I got bored and closed the game.  It's a major problem in almost every one of the levels.  

- Lots of repetitive gameplay.  I enjoy jumping, then turning around, and jumping again... but I don't really enjoy doing the exact same jump 8 times in a row.  There are a lot of areas in the level that are very long, skinny platforms that just take a long time to walk across, and there's really no reason for them to be that long.  Same with several climbing-up-the-wall segments.  Moving through some of these levels feels like a chore.

- Levels don't do a good job at eaching mechanics at all.  About 8 or 9 levels in, you're finally shown the sort of "ice platform" where you can get a lot of speed, but the game hasn't explained the mechanic at all, and never gave you the chance to really learn what to do with it.  That point in the level is preceded with... just a bunch of very easy to traverse moving platforms.  The dev could easily have taken the earlier parts of the level to gradually introduce the ice mechanic, but instead just makes you do it once for a HUGE jump that isn't intuitive at all.

- Levels are just... not elegantly designed.  They feel thrown together.  Huge walls that are huge for no reason.  Some levels have multiple routes, some have a single route that's not obvious at all.  Lots of random jumping on tiny platforms.  

You can excuse some of this, the game comes with a built-in level editor, but I really hope that the dev takes some time and goes through each level with some more care.  Early levels should be teaching one or two mechanics, gradually increasing their difficulty, and then testing your mastery of those mechanics.  It's honestly missing that pretty much entirely as of right now.

26397309.review:
很好玩很耐玩很耗体力的一个攀爬类VR游戏。主要靠两个操作，一是双手按手柄侧键摆动手臂走路或跑步，二是双手按扳机甩动手臂跳跃，很容易学会，但是要掌握好力度并不容易，尤其是跳跃，要多练习。

很考验臂力，我刚开始玩时，由于力度掌握不好，太过用力，结果竟然玩到手臂酸疼，现在熟悉操作了，没刚开始玩时那么吃力了，但仍然是一个比较耗体力的游戏。

虽然只需要用到简单的两个操作，但关卡的设计令到这游戏乐趣无穷。比如，其中一关，有一个类似跑道的设计，你跳向那条跑道，会有冲刺的效果，你必须冲刺才能到达目的地，不然太远了，冲刺速度飞快，你要控制好方向，不然会掉下去。

游戏默认的移动方式其实已经做到令大部分人不晕，开发商依然很贴心地设计了几种方式减轻易晕玩家的眩晕（并不影响核心玩法），设置了后，相信都不会晕了。

作为攀爬类游戏，虽然场景不是现实风格，但也正是得益于这种看似简单、实则变化无穷的场景，能够用来做创意工坊，再加上能联机比赛和合作，所以，不愁通关后没内容玩。

最后，温馨提示，恐高慎玩！注意手柄！玩之前最好清理好周边的东西，记得系好手柄的绑带，这是一个需要用力甩手柄的游戏，甩到东西或墙壁的话，随时报废！

TL;DR Worth $10, especially if you like level editors and playing levels made by other players. Hands down, best VR climbing game out at the time of this review. No question.

I have been having a lot of fun with this game. I'm sure it will also be one of the games I show friends after they get the hang of VR. 

With the level editor and nice steamworkshop so you can try out other people's levels, I think this game is worth $10. I spent about an hour in the level editor and made a really cool level and submitted it. Right now there are only a few levels. It's looking like a few new levels are coming out each day. There'll probably be more this weekend since that'll give players the freetime to make more levels. If you were to just play the levels the game comes with, you'd finish the game in maybe 45 minutes to an hour.

Unfortunlatly I couldn't find anyone online. It seems like one of those things where you and your friend have to agree to get online at the same time. The main problem I think is that the lobby forces someone to stand in an empty room and wait. This is a problem because it's super boring to wait, so the longest I've been able to make myself wait is about 3 minutes before I give up and just play singleplayer. Assuming everyone else is like me, there would never be any games online. I think it's be great if players could join you mid game. If the dev is looking for a method that involves writing no code, at least make the waiting room more of an open playground or something. Hell, just swap out that empty box room with the demo level. That'd be perfect.

The number 1 reason why I love this game is the feeling of "Don't look down, don't look down, shit I looked down." Is soooo terrifying! The higher up I climb, the more I feel like I could fall and die. If you love being scared of heights in VR, you will absolutly love this game. 26228936.review:
This may be my new favorite VR experience. After trying the demo I was hooked by the way it felt to basically do super-human VR parkour. I would HIGHLY recommend trying the demo, especially since it is free and you have nothing to lose. Even though it is limited it does a great job showcasing the potential with the game. However, I wasn't prepared for the feeling I would have going through the various levels in the full game.  

The game's movement mechanics really lend themselves to VR and is what sets this game apart from anything else on the Vive. It's easy to get completely immersed once you start pumping your arms like a sprinter and start swinging around and flying through the air like some sort of crossfit Spiderman. The amount of freedom you have when completing the level is what I really love about the game and it utilizes room scale nicely. There are so many ways to tackle the various obstacles and challenges that are placed before you. Also since there is a more natural mapping to how your actions translate to movement in the game I didn't experience any type of motion sickness whatsoever and felt empowered beyond imagination. However, if you do get motion sickness there are options to help minimize this.

There were two moments I experienced that really blew me away and solidified this game as one of my favorites. The first is when instead of trying to climb across a beam to cross a gap I decided to just jump as high and far as I could. After swinging my arms downward as hard as I could I basically did a Hulk jump and somehow landed directly on the goal after flying through the air for a few seconds. The second was when I had to reach a goal that was below me that I had to reach while flying through the air at high speed. Based on my trajectory it looked like I was going to barely miss it so I dove on the ground backwards at the last second and was able to barely grab the goal.

The fact that this game will have online play AND a level editor which allows for community created content makes me fully anticipate that the replay value for this game will be off the charts. I can't wait to see what this game becomes because right now it is looking like it may be the start of something epic!

40268435.review:
This game is the best answer to the question "What makes VR different from 2d?"

The first time you're so high up you feel your head swoon, you'll be stomping the floor to try and get your mind to stop being scared, and it just won't work.

The movement system is incredibly intuitive where you basically throw yourself and click to grab. Game has artificial locomotion so it might make some people queasy but honestly most people seem to enjoy it even in the first level.

But if you really dedicate yourself to the awesome community maps you can pull off death defying climbs. I spent like 4 hours climbing a scale version of the Eiger Mountain North Face of the Alps. It was amazing because they had little facts about the real expeditions that climbed them, and you can really feel like you're part of something and doing something truly thrilling.

I would also say that this game is probably the best 3d platforming control system for VR that we'll ever get, as far as precise control and non-teleport. It is downright fun and there's so many maps to choose from on top of the 15 included to teach you the mechanics. 

Better still the Dev loves playing his own game and plays all the time and you can chat with him. Not to mention the game features snow during holidays, halloween masks and outfits during halloween and so many other little easter eggs.

Playing online is also a MUST. Even if you don't hang around to chat, the first time someone lowers their hand down to help you up is amazingly immersive.

I literally play a map any time I get stressed out at work, I come home and have a good climb. Something about the adrenaline drops from falling or just being high up really puts the day's concerns to rest. You get to that flag and suddenly you feel very accomplished, as you pushed through your nervousness with the heights and the trials of the climb itself which too strategy and reflex.

40069927.review:
The game itself is incredibly satisfying, the limited checkpoint mechanic is a great way of adding a tense strategic moment before every leap: "Should I put the flag down here?"

It does locomotion incredibly well; despite the whole purpose of the game being movement, I've rarely felt any issues with motion sickness at all, except on rare occasions when starting to fall.

The inbuilt maps are great - wish there was more of them. Fortunately, the community built maps are also very well done, and fill that gap nicely.

My biggest regret is that the floating eye doesn't seem to have any more dialogue

39927317.review: Very fun game, but I would recommend playing this with some irl friends, and race eachother, because the game gets a bit repetitive and boring after a while. So you kind of need to create your own game out of it.

39854909.review:
This truly is one of the BEST games you can play in VR, regardless if you play single player, or coop with a friend, or even just online with new people is a blast. You may want to get your "VR legs" ready first, in some other games, as this has a lot of movement. However it's not bad at all, once you settle in to VR. 

It's about what it sounds like, climbing. But you can do all sorts of fun things while progressing through the level. You could throw yourself up the wall fast in a few swings, or slowlly climb it hand over hand. Both methods are fun, all depending what kind of experience you're looking for at the time. Some areas require you to do some fancy hand work and stretching to reach the next point, or if you're experienced, you could throw yourself across and reach for a hand hold, and hope you make it, if you land, you saved a bunch of time, and felt badass doing it, if not, well you can either try again, or just take it slow.

There is also a level editor in game which is very simple, as well as allows for a lot of freedom in creating custom maps, I've already posted one simple map on the workshop, and am working on a second. To add, I've never made maps for any other game before, modded, or with a built in editor. This one is just easy to use, and the style of the game allows for tons of freedom in building your ideas into real climbable maps. 

If you have a friend to play with, it makes playing the game so much more fun, as every level is coop able. What that means, is in coop, you can help eachother with obstacles, like grabbing their hand and lifting them up to a handhold, or riding on your friends back to stretch out further. It's all so much fun to play!

The game supports 360 degree and 180 degree tracking, so if you only have front facing cameras with an oculus, you'll be just fine, as it has a pretty easy snap turning method

And to those wanting to play on a lower end maching, I'm playing on a gtx 1050ti/ i5 3470/24gb ram, and my friend is playing on an identical setup, except he only has 8gb ram. We're both able to play the game at a mostly stable 90fps with no reprojection if we drop the resolution scale to 70-80%. If you're comfortable using ASW or Reprojection, depending if you have oculus or vive. You'll be fine with these system settings playing 100% resolution scale. But my personal preference is to avoid ASW or Reprojection as it just feels a bit better when you get a proper 90fps, even if that means making the game look a little worse.

I absolutely recomend this game to everyone who owns any VR system!
